text: Drugs in the Workplace 1 Drugs in the Workplace Quick Facts • 77% of illegal drug users are employed. • 1 in 12 workers admits to using drugs, with marijuana most commonly used. • 40% of fatalities and 47% of injuries in the workplace are linked to substance abuse. • Drug users consume almost twice the benefits as non-users and make twice as many workers’ compensation claims. • Drug users have higher instances of theft, turnover, and workplace violence. • Drug users are routinely less

productive at work and their work performance suffers measurably. • Employee drug use is nearly twice as prevalent in smaller businesses. • Drug abuse costs employers more than $25 Billion annually in lost productivity. Overview of Drug-Free Workplace Policy The Drug-Free Workplace Policy Establishes a clear message that drug use in the workplace is prohibited and encourages employees who have substance abuse problems to voluntarily seek help. Drug-Free Workplace Policy exists to protect the

health and safety of all employees, customers, and the public. It also helps to maintain product quality, company integrity and reputation, and comply with the Drug-Free Workplace Act of 1988 or any other applicable laws. Impact of Substance Abuse Employee Health. People who abuse drugs tend to neglect nutrition, sleep, and other basic health needs. Substance abuse depresses the immune system. Its impact on the workplace includes higher use of health benefits, increased use of sick time and

higher absenteeism and tardiness. Productivity. Employees who are substance abusers can be physically and mentally impaired while on the job. Substance abuse interferes with job satisfaction and the motivation to do a good job. Its impact on the workplace includes reduced output; increased errors; lower quality of work and reduced customer satisfaction. Decision Making. Individuals who abuse drugs often make poor decisions and have a distorted perception of their ability. Here, substance abuse’s

impact on the Drugs in the Workplace 2 workplace includes reduced innovation; reduced creativity; less competitiveness; and poor decisions, both daily and strategic. Safety. Common effects of substance abuse include impaired vision, hearing, and muscle coordination and low levels of attention, alertness, and mental acuity. Its impact on the workplace includes increased accidents, and more workers’ compensation claims. Employee Morale. The presence of an employee with drug problems creates a

strain on relationships between coworkers. Organizations that appear to condone substance abuse create the impression that they do not care. Impact on the workplace includes higher turnover; lower quality; and reduced team effort. Security. Employees with drug problems often have financial difficulties, and employees who use illegal drugs may be engaging in illegal activities in the workplace. In this area, substance abuse’s impact on the workplace can include theft and law enforcement

involvement. Organizational Image and Community Relations. Accidents, lawsuits, and other incidents stemming from employee substance abuse problems may receive media attention and hurt an organization’s reputation in the community. The impact of drug abuse on the workplace includes reduced trust and confidence; and reduced ability to attract high-quality employees. Reasons for Drugs Use The first is “use,” where drugs may be used in a socially accepted or medically authorized manner to modify or

control mood or state of mind. An example includes taking an anti-anxiety agent as prescribed by a physician. There are additional ways people use drugs without necessarily becoming addicted. Experimentation – Out of curiosity and/or at the urging of peers, individuals may try using drugs illegally. If the illegal drug use is not repeated, or discontinues after a short time, such experimentation may not be problematic. Social or Recreational – Some people may choose to use or be pressured into

using substances in social or recreational situations. As a Stress Reliever – Many people use drugs to help them cope with pressure or stress. If this type of use is infrequent and does not create more stress or difficulties for the user, or those around him or her, it may not lead to addiction. Drugs in the Workplace 3 Defining Abuse When the use of a substance to modify or control mood or state of mind is in a manner that is illegal or harmful to oneself or others, it is considered problematic

use, or abuse. Examples of potential consequences of harmful use are: • Accidents or injuries; • Blackouts; • Legal problems; • Poor job performance; • Family problems. Understanding Addiction A number of individuals occasionally use drugs without becoming addicted, but for many, abuse continues despite repeated attempts to return to more social or controlled use and leads to addiction. Addiction is the irresistible compulsion to use drugs despite adverse consequences. It is characterized by

repeated failures to control use, increased tolerance and increased disruption in the family. Unfortunately, it is not possible to tell early on whose use may lead to abuse and/or addiction. For one in ten people, abuse leads to addiction. Types of Drug Addiction: Chronic – Once you have developed an addiction, you will always have to deal with it. You may manage to stop using drugs for significant periods of time, but for most, the disease does not disappear but rather goes into remission.

Should you attempt to resume ‘normal’ use, you will rapidly return to addictive, out of control use and abuse. Progressive – Addiction gets worse over time. With some drugs, the decline is rapid; with others, it can be more gradual, but it does get worse. Drugs cause a biochemical change in the nervous system that can persist even after the substance leaves the blood. Repeated use causes progressive damage. Primary – Addiction is not just a symptom of some underlying psychological problem, a

developmental stage or a reaction to stress. Once your use of drugs has become an addiction, the addiction itself needs to be medically treated as a primary illness. Terminal – Addiction to drugs often leads to disease and possibly death. Characterized by Denial – One of the most disturbing and confusing aspects of addiction is that it is characterized by denial. The user denies that his or her use is out of control or that it is causing any problems at home or work. The user often seems to be

the last to know that his or her life is out of control. There are effective Drugs in the Workplace 4 strategies employed by professionals for helping to break through this denial, which must be overcome before treatment can take place. Risk of Addiction It is important to know that addiction is a family disease: Some people with a history of substance abuse in their family are more susceptible to developing problems with addiction. Children of drug addicts are three times as likely to develop

problems. If both parents are drug addicts the risk increases to five times as great. This is due to heredity as well as learned behavior. It is important for parents to realize that children learn much more from watching their behavior than listening to their advice. Prior abuse of drugs has a great impact on developing future problems: A pattern of abuse develops and can lead to addiction and psychological reliance on drugs. This can be a slow progression for some and a rapid decline for

others. Research demonstrates that the later in life an individual first uses drugs, the less likely he or she will be to become addicted. Other contributing factors: Some people use drugs as part of a self-destructive lifestyle. Other people start to use substances to seek relief from depression or crisis in their lives. Although some fortunate individuals never develop serious problems and use diminishes or ceases once the precipitating events change, others develop a serious problem before

they even realize it. Signs and Symptoms of Substance Abuse Emotional Effects may Include: - Aggression - Burnout - Anxiety - Depression - Paranoia - Denial Behavioral Effects that may be experienced are: - Excessive talking - Impaired coordination - Slowed or slurred speech - Inability to sit still - Slow reaction time - Poor motivation and lack of energy - Irritability - Limited attention span Physical Effects Include: - Weight loss - Sweating - Chills Drugs in the Workplace 5 Families and

coworkers can have a significant impact on an individual’s substance use through “enabling” – an action that someone takes to protect the person with the problem from the consequences of his or her actions. Unfortunately, enabling actually helps the person to NOT deal with his or her problem. Examples include: • Covering Up – Providing alibis, making excuses or even doing an impaired worker’s job rather than confronting the issue that he or she is not meeting expectations; • Rationalizing –

Developing reasons why the person’s continued substance abuse or behavior is understandable or acceptable; • Withdrawing or Avoiding – Avoiding contact with the person that has a problem. • Blaming – Some blame themselves for the person’s continued substance abuse or getting angry at the individual for not trying hard enough to control their use or to get help; • Threatening – Saying that you will take action (such as: ceasing to cover up or taking formal disciplinary action) if the employee

doesn’t control their use, but not following through. Traps that family members and coworkers may fall into include: • Sympathy – Trying to get you involved in their personal problems; • Excuses – Having increasingly improbable explanations for everything that happens; • Apology – Being very sorry and promising to change; • Diversions – Trying to get you to talk about other issues in life or in the workplace; • Innocence – Claiming he or she is not the cause of the problems you observe, but

rather the victim; • Anger – Showing physically intimidating behavior and blaming others; • Pity – Using emotional blackmail to elicit your sympathy and guilt; • Tears – Falling apart and expressing remorse upon confrontation. When it comes to assistance, there are several important things to remember: • First, difficulty performing on the job can sometimes be caused by unrecognized personal problems – including addiction to drugs; • Help is available; • Although a supervisor may suspect that an

employee’s performance is poor because of underlying personal problems, it is up to the employee to decide whether or not that is the case; • Further, it is an employee’s responsibility to decide whether or not to seek help; • Addiction is treatable and reversible; • An employee’s decision to seek help is a private one and will not be made public. Drugs in the Workplace 6 Employee Assistance Program (EAP) Some companies offer EAP (or Employee Assistance Program) services to their employees. • An

EAP can help employees decide what to do if they have a problem with drugs. • An EAP can also help an employee decide what to do if someone in their family or workgroup has a problem. If EAP services are not available, employees can turn to the following for help: • Community hotlines; • Self-help groups such as Narcotics Anonymous; • Community mental health centers; • Private therapists or counselors; • Addiction treatment centers; • SAMHSA Confidentiality is a core principle of EAP services.

Employees need to know that: • Problems will not be made public. • Conversations with an EAP professional or other referral agencies are private and will be protected. • All information related to performance issues will be maintained in his/her personnel file. • Information about any referral to treatment, however, will be kept separately. • Information about treatment for addiction or mental illness is not a matter of public record and cannot be shared without a release signed by the employee.

• If an employee chooses to tell coworkers about his/her private concerns, that is his or her decision. • Finally, when an employee tells his or her supervisor something in confidence, supervisors are obligated to protect that disclosure. If EAP services are available, employees are also assured that: • EAP records are separate from personnel records and can be accessed only with a signed release from the employee; • EAP professionals are bound by a code of ethics to protect the confidentiality

of the employees and family members that they serve; • There are clear limits on when and what information an EAP professional can share and with whom. Drugs in the Workplace 7 However, there are some limits on confidentiality that may require: • Disclosure of child abuse, elder abuse, and serious threats of homicide or suicide as dictated by state law; • Reporting participation in an EAP to the referring supervisor; • Reporting the results of assessment and evaluation following a positive drug

test; • Verifying medical information to authorize release time or satisfy fitness-for-duty concerns as specified in company policy; • Revealing medical information to the insurance company in order to qualify for coverage under a benefits plan. FAA Drug Testing Program The aviation industry can be considered as one of the most highly regulated sectors and has random testing for drugs as required in accordance with regulations 14 CFR 120 and 49 CFR 40 to meet FAA and Department of Transportation

annual testing requirements. In addition, if someone is suspected of being under the influence a random test may be required by a Supervisor or HR that has been properly trained and delegated to make such a decision. Drug testing regulations are strictly imposed to all safety-sensitive employees in the aviation industry to ensure that every employee is fit to perform his duties. FAA-mandated drug testing program includes the following rules: • No one should be hired or transferred to a

safety-sensitive job without having to undergo a pre-employment drug test and must receive a negative test result. • Employees or applicants that are about to take a position for any safety-sensitive function should be checked if they have previously tested positive or have refused to undergo a drug test from their previous employers. • Make sure that employees will undergo random testing, which should be conducted at a minimum rate of 25% for drugs as directed by the division of FAA Drug and

Alcohol Abatement. Refusal of a Drug Test As a result of an employee refusing to take a drug test the following will occur: • Immediate removal from the safety-sensitive duties; • Revocation of FAA certificates and ratings held; and • Typically, probation or termination of employment. Employers are required to report to the FAA’s Federal Air Surgeon all employees who refuse to submit to drug testing. This is applicable to any safety-sensitive employee or an employee who holds a repairman or

mechanic certificate in accordance with regulations 14 CFR 65. Drugs in the Workplace 8 Suspicion of Drug Abuse in the Workplace Everyone is entitled to feel safe in the workplace. We spend as much time at work as we do at home with our families, so expecting a work environment that is free from the effects of drugs is a given. We go to our jobs each day to produce goods or services and to earn an honest living, and that is hindered when a coworker or boss is coming to work intoxicated. Some of

the steps that can be taken in a situation where a coworker seems to be under the influence is to refer to your company’s manual or employee handbook. There is usually an official procedure in place with direction on what to do in situations like this. One approach is to alert your manager or supervisor to the fact that you are aware of an employee who is under the influence. A supervisor can take the appropriate actions to handle the situation, although you may be required to speak to human

resources or an upper-level manager about the incident. Let your manager know if you prefer to remain anonymous. Another way is to talk to the human resources and report the incident. You may have to fill out a report of your observations as to why you believe a co-worker might be under the influence. Last recommendation is to avoid confronting the employee on your own or telling other co-workers about the situation. Doing so will only create the potential for danger and the spreading of rumors.

Your co-workers likely cannot do anything more than you can to resolve the situation anyway, so it is best to tell only management and human resources. Returning to Work after a Violation Employees cannot return to their safety-sensitive functions after a refusal or positive drug test without the following taking place: • Employers must provide the employee a list of Substance Abuse Professionals also known as an SAP. Once the employee has chosen an SAP, a face-to-face evaluation will be set up.

The SAP will be able to provide a complete written report that includes the recommended education and treatment plan, and the content of the evaluation. • After undergoing treatment, the SAP needs to perform a re-evaluation to assess if the employee has successfully completed required education and treatment plan. The SAP will then write a report to the employer indicating the findings from the re-evaluation. • Prior to the employee returning to his safety-sensitive position, he needs to undergo

a return-to-duty drug test under the direct observation of an authorized Drugs in the Workplace 9 professional of the clinic that conducts drug testing. The employee undergoing testing must produce a verified negative drug test result. If a test is positive this will result in additional provisions and a lengthy path to regaining certifications and working in a safety-sensitive position once again, if ever at all. • If an employee can overcome these adversities, future drug testing will be done
under direct supervision as directed by an SAP.
